G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, and any substantial interference with a tenant's use and enjoyment of the premises constitutes a breach of this covenant.

G.L. c. 231..proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the claims in this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14 and G.L. c. 231.

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 281 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: The presence of a persistent rodent infestation constitutes a substantial interference with the Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the premises. See *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 281 (1994) (holding that substantial and recurring interferences may violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment).
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case does support the general principle that substantial and recurring interferences can violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so in the context of drug-related criminal activity in common areas, not rodent infestation. The opinion does not mention rodents or pest infestations, nor does it address whether such conditions constitute substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus, using this case specifically for the proposition about persistent rodent infestation is not accurate, though it is suitable authority for the broader substantial-interference concept.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 100 (1.proposition: Defendant’s failure to resolve the infestation in good faith constitutes a willful or knowing violation of the statute, entitling Plaintiff to statutory damages and attorneys’ fees. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 100 (1982) (noting that a willful or knowing breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14 results in liability for enhanced damages).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 100 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion directly construes G.L. c. 186, § 14, holding that a landlord who at least recklessly interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment is liable for the statute’s enhanced remedy of “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater,” plus attorneys’ fees. The court affirms the availability of attorneys’ fees and explains that “actual and consequential damages” under § 14 include personal injuries such as emotional distress, thereby supporting the use of § 14 for statutory damages and fees where the landlord’s violation is willful, intentional, or reckless.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 100 (1.relevant_excerpt:
“Any person who commits any act in violation of this section shall also be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee…
…we hold that a tenant need not seek a criminal conviction before claiming damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14. Nor must the tenant prove that the landlord intended to interfere with the tenant’s rights, at least as long as the landlord’s conduct was reckless… Therefore, Solomon’s claim for emotional distress was within the scope of § 14, and was properly considered in the determination of attorneys’ fees.”
